Network Working Group S. Kitterman Network Working Group S. Kitterman
Internet-Draft Kitterman Technical Services Internet-Draft fTLD Registry Services
Updates: 7489 (if approved) October 6, 2018 Updates: 7489 (if approved) October 13, 2018
Intended status: Informational Intended status: Informational
Expires: April 9, 2019 Expires: April 16, 2019
DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance) DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance)
Extension For TLDs (Top Level Domains) Extension For PSDs (Public Suffix Domains)
draft-kitterman-dmarc-tld-00 draft-kitterman-dmarc-psd-00
Abstract Abstract
DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and
Conformance) is a scalable mechanism by which a mail-originating Conformance) is a scalable mechanism by which a mail-originating
organization can express domain-level policies and preferences for organization can express domain-level policies and preferences for
message validation, disposition, and reporting, that a mail-receiving message validation, disposition, and reporting, that a mail-receiving
organization can use to improve mail handling. DMARC itself does not organization can use to improve mail handling. DMARC policies can be
apply to domains above the organizational level, such as TLDs (Top applied at the individual domain level or for a set of domains at the
Level Domains). For the subset of TLDs (or other non-organizational organizational level. The design of DMARC precludes grouping
domains) that require DMARC usage, it is appropriate to provide TLD policies for a set of domains above the organizational level, such as
level DMARC capability. This memo describes an extension to DMARC to TLDs (Top Level Domains). These types of domains (which are not all
enable a subset of DMARC functionality for such domains. at the top level of the DNS tree) can be collectively referred to as
Public Suffix Domains (PSDs). For the subset of PSDs that require
DMARC usage, it is appropriate to provide PSD level DMARC capability
to provide policy and collect feedback for a set of domains. This
memo describes an extension to DMARC to enable a subset of DMARC
functionality for such domains.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
DMARC [RFC7489] provides email sending organizational policy DMARC [RFC7489] provides email sending organizational policy
information to email receivers. Due to the design of DMARC [RFC7489] information to email receivers. DMARC [RFC7489] allows policy to be
and the nature of the Internet email architecture [RFC5598], there specified for both individual domains and sets of domains within a
are interoperability issues associated with DMARC [RFC7489] single organization. For domains above the organizational level in
deployment. These are discussed in Interoperability Issues between the DNS tree, they are currently limited to expressing policy for the
DMARC and Indirect Email Flows [RFC7960]. These issues are not exact domain. There is no method available to such domains to
applicable to TLDs, since they do not send mail. express lower level policy or receive feedback reporting for sets of
domains. This prevents policy declarations for non-existent domains
and identification of domain abuse in email, which can be important
for brand and consumer protection.
DMARC [RFC7489], by design, does not support requirements of TLD As an example, imagine a country code TLD (ccTLD) which has
operators. For TLDs that require use of DMARC [RFC7489], a subset of subdomains for government and commercial use (.gov.example and
DMARC reporting and enforcement capability is needed for TLD .com.example). Within the .gov.example public suffix, use of DMARC
operators to effectively manage and monitor implementation of TLD [RFC7489] has been mandated and .gov.example has published its own
DMARC [RFC7489] record:
"v=DMARC1;p=reject;rua=mailto:dmarc@dmarc.service.gov.example"
at
_dmarc.gov.example.
This would provide policy and feedback for mail sent from
@gov.example, but not @tax.gov.example and there is no way to publish
an organizational level policy that would do so. While, in theory,
receivers could reject mail from non-existent domains, in practice
there are operational issues with doing so that make it impractical.
Non-existence of the sending domain is often a factor in a mail
delivery decision, but not generally treated as definitive on its
own.
This memo provides a simple extension to DMARC [RFC7489] to allow
operators of Public Suffix Domains (PSDs) to express policy for
groups of subdomains, extends the DMARC [RFC7489] policy query
functionality to detect and process such a policy, describes receiver
feedback for such policies, and provides controls to mitigate
potential privacy considerations associated with this extension.
There are two types of Public Suffix Operators (PSOs) for which this
extension would be useful and appropriate:
o Branded PSDs (e.g., ".google"): These domains are effectively
organizational domains as discussed in DMARC [RFC7489]. They
control all subdomains of the tree. The ".gov.example" used above
is an example of this class.
o Multi-organization PSDs that require DMARC usage (e.g., ".bank"):
Because existing organizational domains using this PSD have their
own DMARC policy, the applicability of this extension is for non-
existent domains. The extension allows the brand protection
benefits of DMARC [RFC7489] to extend to the entire PSD, including
cousin domains of registere organizations.
Due to the design of DMARC [RFC7489] and the nature of the Internet
email architecture [RFC5598], there are interoperability issues
associated with DMARC [RFC7489] deployment. These are discussed in
Interoperability Issues between DMARC and Indirect Email Flows
[RFC7960]. These issues are not applicable to PSDs, since they do
not send mail.
DMARC [RFC7489], by design, does not support requirements of PSD
operators. For PSDs that require use of DMARC [RFC7489], a subset of
DMARC reporting and enforcement capability is needed for PSD
operators to effectively manage and monitor implementation of PSD
requirements. requirements.
2. Terminology and Definitions 2. Terminology and Definitions
This section defines terms used in the rest of the document. This section defines terms used in the rest of the document.

"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and
"OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in
BCP 14 [RFC2119] [RFC8174] when, and only when, they appear in all BCP 14 [RFC2119] [RFC8174] when, and only when, they appear in all
capitals, as shown here. capitals, as shown here.
2.2. Top Level Domain (TLD) 2.2. Public Suffix Domain (PSD)
The global Internet Domain Name System (DNS) is documented in The global Internet Domain Name System (DNS) is documented in
numerous Requests for Comment (RFC). It defines a tree of names numerous Requests for Comment (RFC). It defines a tree of names
starting with root, ".", immediately below which are Top Level Domain starting with root, ".", immediately below which are Top Level Domain
names such as ".com" and ".us". The usage for TLD DMARC is broader names such as ".com" and ".us". They are not available for private
and includes all domains above the organizational level in the tree, registration. In many cases the public portion of the DNS tree is
e.g., ".gov.uk". more than one level deep. PSD DMARC includes all public domains
above the organizational level in the tree, e.g., ".gov.uk".
2.3. TLD Operator (TLDO) 2.3. Longest PSD
A TLD Operator manages operations within their TLD. Organizational Domain with one label removed.
2.4. TLDO Controlled Domain Names 2.4. Public Suffix Operator (PSO)
TLDO Controlled Domain Names are names in the DNS that are managed by A Public Suffix Operator manages operations within their PSD.
a TLDO and are not available for use as Organizational Domains (the
2.5. PSO Controlled Domain Names
PSO Controlled Domain Names are names in the DNS that are managed by
a PSO and are not available for use as Organizational Domains (the
term organizational domains is defined in DMARC [RFC7489]). term organizational domains is defined in DMARC [RFC7489]).
Depending on TLD policy, these will have one (e.g., ".com") or more Depending on PSD policy, these will have one (e.g., ".com") or more
(e.g., ".co.uk") name components. (e.g., ".co.uk") name components.
2.5. Non-existent Domains 2.6. Non-existent Domains
For DMARC [RFC7489] purposes, a non-existent domain is a domain name For DMARC [RFC7489] purposes, a non-existent domain is a domain name
that publishes none of A, AAAA, or MX records. This is a broader that publishes none of A, AAAA, or MX records. This is a broader
definition than that in NXDOMAIN [RFC8020]. definition than that in NXDOMAIN [RFC8020].
3. TLD DMARC Updates to DMARC Requirements 3. PSD DMARC Updates to DMARC Requirements
This document updates DMARC [RFC7489] as follows: This document updates DMARC [RFC7489] as follows:
3.1. General Updates 3.1. General Updates
References to "Domain Owners" also apply to TLDOs. References to "Domain Owners" also apply to PSOs.
3.2. Section 6.1 DMARC Policy Record 3.2. Section 6.1 DMARC Policy Record
TLD DMARC records are published as a subdomain of the TLD. For the PSD DMARC records are published as a subdomain of the PSD. For the
TLD ".example", the TLDO would post DMARC preferences in a TXT record PSD ".example", the PSO would post DMARC preferences in a TXT record
at "_dmarc.example". at "_dmarc.example".
3.3. Section 6.5. Domain Owner Actions 3.3. Section 6.5. Domain Owner Actions
In addition to the DMARC [RFC7489] domain owner actions, TLDOs will In addition to the DMARC [RFC7489] domain owner actions, PSOs will
need to update the "DMARC Top Level Domain (TLD) Registry". This need to update the "DMARC Public Suffix Domain (PSD) Registry". This
registry is defined in Section 6.1. registry is defined in Section 6.1.
3.4. Section 6.6.3. Policy Discovery 3.4. Section 6.6.3. Policy Discovery
A new step between step 3 and 4 is added: A new step between step 3 and 4 is added:
3A. If the set is now empty and the TLD of the Organizational Domain 3A. If the set is now empty and the longest PSD (Section 2.3) of the
is listed in the DMARC TLD Registry, the Mail Receiver MUST query Organizational Domain is listed in the DMARC PSD Registry (defined
the DNS for a DMARC TXT record at the DNS domain matching the in Section 6.1), the Mail Receiver MUST query the DNS for a DMARC
Organizational Domain with one label removed in place of the TXT record at the DNS domain matching the longest PSD
RFC5322.From domain in the message (if different). A possibly (Section 2.3) in place of the RFC5322.From domain in the message
empty set of records is returned. (if different). A possibly empty set of records is returned.
As an example, for a message with the Organizational Domain of As an example, for a message with the Organizational Domain of
"example.compute.amazonaws.com.cn", the query for TLD DMARC would use "example.compute.cloudcompany.com.cctld", the query for PSD DMARC
"_dmarc.compute.amazonaws.com.cn". would use "compute.cloudcompany.com.cctld" as the longest PSD
(Section 2.3). The receiver would check to see if that PSD is listed
in the DMARC PSD Registry, and if so, perform the policy lookup at
"_dmarc.compute.cloudcompany.com.cctld".
Note: Because the PSD policy query comes after the Organizational
Domain policy query, PSD policy is not used for Organizational
domains that have published a DMARC [RFC7489] policy. Specifically,
this is not a mechanism to provide feedback addresses (RUA/RUF) when
an Organizational Domain has declined to do so.
3.5. Section 7. DMARC Feedback 3.5. Section 7. DMARC Feedback
Operational note for TLD DMARC: For TLDOs, feedback for non-existent Operational note for PSD DMARC: For PSOs, feedback for non-existent
domains is desired and useful. Because of the constraints on TLD domains is desired and useful. Because of the constraints on PSD
DMARC scope, there are not significant privacy considerations DMARC scope, there are not significant privacy considerations
associated with this reporting (See Section 4). associated with this reporting (See Section 4).
4. Privacy Considerations 4. Privacy Considerations
This document does not significantly change the Privacy This document does not significantly change the Privacy
Considerations of [RFC7489]. Considerations of [RFC7489].
4.1. Feedback leakage 4.1. Feedback leakage
Providing feedback reporting to TLDOs can, in some cases, create Providing feedback reporting to PSOs can, in some cases, create
leakage of information outside of an organization to the TLDO. There leakage of information outside of an organization to the PSO. There
are roughly three cases to consider: are roughly three cases to consider:
o Branded TLDs (e.g., ".google"), RUA and RUF reports based on TLD o Branded PSDs (e.g., ".google"), RUA and RUF reports based on PSD
DMARC have the potential to contain information about emails DMARC have the potential to contain information about emails
related to entities managed by the organization. Since both the related to entities managed by the organization. Since both the
TLDO and the Organizational Domain owners are common, there is no PSO and the Organizational Domain owners are common, there is no
privacy risk for either normal or Non-existent Domain reporting. privacy risk for either normal or Non-existent Domain reporting.
o Multi-organization TLDs that require DMARC usage (e.g., ".bank"): o Multi-organization PSDs that require DMARC usage (e.g., ".bank"):
TLD DMARC based reports will only be generated for domains that do PSD DMARC based reports will only be generated for domains that do
not publish a DMARC policy at the organizational level. For not publish a DMARC policy at the organizational level. For
domains that do publish the required DMARC policy records, the domains that do publish the required DMARC policy records, the
feedback reporting addresses (RUA and RUF) of the organization feedback reporting addresses (RUA and RUF) of the organization
will be used. Since TLD DMARC is limited to TLDs that mandate will be used. Since PSD DMARC is limited to PSDs that mandate
organizational domains publish DMARC policy for existing domains, organizational domains publish DMARC policy for existing domains,
the risk of this issue is limited to organizational domains that the risk of this issue is limited to organizational domains that
are out of compliance with TLD policy. are out of compliance with PSD policy.
o Multi-organization TLDs (e.g., ".com") that do not mandate DMARC o Multi-organization PSDs (e.g., ".com") that do not mandate DMARC
usage. Privacy risks for organizational domains within such TLDs usage. Privacy risks for organizational domains within such PSDs
would be significant. This is mitigated by the limitation to only would be significant. This is mitigated by the limitation to only
include TLDs listed in the public IANA DMARC TLD Registry include PSDs listed in the public IANA DMARC PSD Registry
described in Section 6.1. described in Section 6.1.
TLDOs will receive feedback on non-existant domains, which may be PSOs will receive feedback on non-existent domains, which may be
similar to existing organizational domains. Feedback related to such similar to existing organizational domains. Feedback related to such
cousin domains have a small risk of carrying information related to cousin domains have a small risk of carrying information related to
an actual organizational domain. To minimize this potential concern, an actual organizational domain. To minimize this potential concern,
TLD DMARC feedback is best limited to Aggregate Reports. Feedback PSD DMARC feedback is best limited to Aggregate Reports. Feedback
Reports carry more detailed information and present a greater risk. Reports carry more detailed information and present a greater risk.

6. IANA Considerations 6. IANA Considerations
This section describes actions requested to be completed by IANA. This section describes actions requested to be completed by IANA.
6.1. DMARC Top Level Domain (TLD) Registry 6.1. DMARC Public Suffix Domain (PSD) Registry
IANA is requested to create a new DMARC Top Level Domain (TLD) IANA is requested to create a new DMARC Public Suffix Domain (PSD)
Registry within the Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, Registry within the Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting,
and Conformance (DMARC) Parameters Registry. and Conformance (DMARC) Parameters Registry.
Names of TLDs participating in TLD DMARC must be registered with IANA Names of PSDs participating in PSD DMARC must be registered with IANA
in this new sub-registry. New entries are assigned only for TLDs in this new sub-registry. New entries are assigned only for PSDs
that require use of DMARC. The requirement has to be documented in a that require use of DMARC. The requirement has to be documented in a
manner that satisfies the terms of Expert Review, per [RFC5226]. The manner that satisfies the terms of Expert Review, per [RFC5226]. The
Designated Expert needs to confirm that provided documentation Designated Expert needs to confirm that provided documentation
adequately describes TLD policy to require domain owners to use DMARC adequately describes PSD policy to require domain owners to use DMARC
or that all domain owners are part of a single organization with the or that all domain owners are part of a single organization with the
TLDO. PSO.
